;枪手袭击;莫斯科附近的音乐厅;，造成至少 139 人死亡。这是自 2004 年别斯兰学校围攻以来;俄罗斯;最严重的恐怖事件。伊斯兰国在中亚的一个分支机构声称对此负责。四名被指控的袭击者出庭受审，受到严重瘀伤和殴打，面临恐怖主义指控。当局称这些人来自塔吉克斯坦。美国驻莫斯科大使馆在三月初就曾发出袭击警告，并告诉其公民避免大型集会。俄罗斯无视这一警告。相反，弗拉基米尔·普京和俄罗斯媒体却公然试图将这次袭击与乌克兰联系起来。一家电视频道播放了乌克兰官员对这一事件欢呼雀跃的虚假视频片段。

;

;俄罗斯加强了对;乌克兰的无人机和导弹袭击;，在<小>;伊斯兰国;袭击莫斯科之前不久加强了他们的行动。首都基辅受到袭击，全国各地的能源基础设施都受到攻击。当一枚俄罗斯导弹误入其领空时，波兰紧急出动战斗机。

;

;;保加利亚;似乎正在前往另一个国家这是三年来第六次选举，该国各政党未能就“团结”政府达成一致，这威胁到保加利亚在 2025 年初采用欧元作为其货币的努力。极右翼和亲俄罗斯政党正在取得进展。< /p>;

;西蒙·哈里斯 (Simon Harris) 被选为;爱尔兰统一党;新任领导人，并将成为该国总理里奥·瓦拉德卡 (Leo Varadkar) 辞职后。哈里斯先生现年 37 岁，将成为担任该职位的最年轻的人。

;;

;一切都与象征意义

;

; <小>;联合国;安理会通过了一项决议，要求;以色列和哈马斯在斋月剩余时间内暂时停火，美国投了弃权票，美国曾使用否决权阻止了三项军事行动。早些时候的决议呼吁停止加沙的战斗。由于对美国的弃权感到愤怒，以色列取消了代表团计划访问华盛顿的计划，并表示，在哈马斯仍扣押以色列人质的情况下，以色列不会停止行动。

;

;;;塞内加尔选民;; 大批民众投票选举反对派候选人巴西鲁·迪奥马耶·法耶 (Bassirou Diomaye Faye) 为总统。即将卸任的总统 Macky Sall 试图推迟选举，导致旷日持久的宪法危机。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;南非;法院裁定由前总统雅各布·祖马支持的政党可以参加定于五月底举行的大选。根据最近的民意调查，uMkhonto we Sizwe 党可能会获得超过 10% 的选票，这可能会将执政的非洲人国民大会党推至 40% 左右，迫使其在希望组建政府的情况下寻求联合政府。

;

;美国、英国和新西兰指责中国;;网络间谍活动;;针对各种目标，包括英国选举委员会、新西兰选举委员会议会和中国共产党的批评者。美国和英国对一组中国黑客的涉嫌幌子公司实施了制裁。他们还对该组织的两名涉嫌成员实施了制裁，而美国则对他们和其他五名男子提出了刑事指控。

;

;高等法院英国给了;朱利安·阿桑奇;更多的时间来反对将他引渡到美国接受间谍指控，并裁定美国政府必须为在那里审判的公正性等提供更多保证。阿桑奇先生在他的维基解密网站上泄露了大量机密信息，美国人称这些信息将生命置于危险之中。

;

;; < a href="https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2024/03/27/nicolas-maduros-sham-election-the-sequel">;委内瑞拉;;主要反对派联盟是被阻止登记参加七月的总统选举并错过了截止日期。 80 岁的哲学家科里娜·尤里斯 (Corina Yoris) 在高级反对派人物被捕后的最后一刻被征召入伍。玛丽亚·科里纳·马查多去年以压倒性优势赢得反对党初选，但被最高法院禁止参选。

;

;美国国务院表示，在首席部长 Arvind Kejriwal 被捕后，正在跟踪;印度;的法律进展德里的一位高级反对派政治家。凯杰里瓦尔被捕之际，距离大选仅几周时间。他因涉及德里酒精政策的腐败案件而被拘留，他称该政策是“捏造的”。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;美国和;日本; 正在准备加强军事同盟，具体细节将在日本首相岸田文雄4月10日访问白宫时公布。该计划包括重组指挥链，这将使国防规划更加顺利。与此同时，日本内阁签署了一项协议，将与英国和意大利共同开发的战斗机出售给其他国家，进一步削弱了日本的和平主义立场。

;

;;泰国;议会下院以压倒性多数投票通过同性婚姻合法化、继承权平等等。该法案是政府的优先事项。如果如预期那样，上议院和国王批准该法律，该法律将于今年年底生效，使泰国成为东南亚第一个同性恋婚礼合法化的国家。

;

;在共和党和民主党再次在最后一刻达成避免政府关门的协议后，乔·拜登签署了一项价值 1.2 万亿美元的;支出措施;，将其纳入法律。该立法本应在六个月前通过。众议院中叛逆的共和党人再次提出罢免议长的可能性。

;;的弗朗西斯斯科特基大桥;巴尔的摩;;一艘集装箱船与其一根支撑柱相撞后倒塌。桥上的六名工人落入水中身亡。美国东海岸的贸易枢纽巴尔的摩港将受到干扰数月。

;

;

;上诉法院同意< b>;唐纳德·特朗普;请求仅支付民事欺诈审判中对他判处的 4.54 亿美元罚款的一部分。法院告诉特朗普，在他对原判决提出上诉期间，他可以缴纳 1.75 亿美元的保证金。然而，特朗普的宽慰是短暂的。不久之后，一名法官驳回了他因向色情明星支付封口费而推迟刑事审判的请求。审判将于 4 月 15 日开始。

;

;;;美国司法部对;;苹果;;，指责科技巨头让客户更难更换手机，破坏应用程序创新，并给开发商、企业和消费者带来“巨大成本”。该投诉实际上试图阻止苹果将用户锁定在其生态系统中。苹果表示，该诉讼“威胁到了我们作为一家公司的身份”，并树立了“一个危险的先例，使政府能够在设计人们的技术时采取严厉措施”。此案需要数年时间才能通过法院审理。

;
;
;
;< /div>;

;同时，欧盟对 Alphabet 和 Apple 的应用商店竞争行为展开调查，而 Meta关于其在广告中使用个人信息的问题。这是根据;欧盟;新的;数字市场法案;对科技公司进行的首次正式审查。 ;欧盟反垄断专员表示，如果这些问题“仅通过讨论就能与公司解决，那么现在就已经解决了”。

;

;;阿里巴巴;放弃了其物流部门的;首次公开募股;计划，转而提出收购该业务少数股东的股份。一年前，这家中国科技巨头宣布打算拆分为六个部分，每个部分都有可能寻求股票上市。但该计划并没有令投资者兴奋。去年年底，阿里巴巴决定不剥离其云部门，并暂停了其超市部门的 ;IPO;。

;

; ;Reddit; 的股价保留了其在纽约证券交易所成功上市所获得的大部分收益。该社交媒体平台的股价在交易首日飙升 48%。

;

;;日元;跌至兑美元汇率创34年来新低，引发日本官员警告称他们可能会干预货币市场。日本央行近期自2007年以来首次加息，这通常会导致日元走强，但其货币政策仍然相对宽松。

;;

;负债累累

;

;华盛顿无党派国会预算办公室主任再次警告称，美国面临着迫在眉睫的;联邦债务危机;，该债务目前处于到 2023 年底，将达到 26 万美元，占 GDP 的 97%。菲利普·斯瓦格尔 (Phillip Swagel) 提出，市场可能对美国偿还债务的能力失去信心，类似于利兹·特拉斯 (Liz Truss) 政府所面临的情况2022 年 10 月在英国举行。今年早些时候，斯瓦格尔先生表示，美国已进入债务上升和债务同时支付的“缓慢螺旋”。

;;
;;< /div>;

;;土耳其央行;将主要利率提高五个百分点至 50%，令市场大吃一惊。一年前该比率为8.5%。由于年通胀率接近 70%，该银行表示将维持紧缩的货币政策，直到观察到物价涨幅“显着且持续下降”。

;

;英国政府已将其持股比例降至略低于 30% 的门槛，不再是 NatWest 集团的控股股东。 2008 年金融危机期间，政府救助了;苏格兰皇家银行;，使其免于崩溃。 2020 年，;RBS; 更名为 NatWest Group（以 ;RBS; 和 NatWest 品牌提供零售银行业务）。危机过去十六年后，政府仍然预计 NatWest 集团要到 2026 年才能完全私有化。

;

;;Visa; 和 ;万事达卡; 同意限制美国的信用卡刷卡费用，结束了与零售商长达两年的斗争，并可能在五年内为商家节省 300 亿美元。该协议还允许零售商向在收银台使用信用卡的顾客收取费用，同时引导他们选择更便宜的选择。

;

;言论自由倡导者

;

;法官驳回了 X 对反数字仇恨中心提起的诉讼，该中心涉嫌开展一项活动，将广告商赶出该平台。 ;CCDH; 发布了一份报告，据称显示 Twitter 上的仇恨言论有所增加，正如当时的情况一样，该报告的所有者埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 将其描述为危言耸听。但法官在严厉的判决中发现，此案完全是为了“惩罚被告的言论”。

;;E;;veryone wants; to know whether Donald Trump will return to白宫。 Yet few understand the intricacies of the electoral system that will decide if he does. This week we published a detailed analysis, not of the broad trends that might affect the vote, but of the peculiarities of this year's race. How likely is it that a third-party candidate will tip a crucial swing state? Or that Mr Trump's criminal trials will sway undecided voters, or fire up his supporters? Or that age will hobble either President Joe Biden or his slightly younger rival? There could be big surprises between now and November.

;

;How to illustrate this? One idea was to show a voter receiving a surprise—in this case, a rather unpleasant one, as he fell through a hole in a voting booth. A variation on this theme was to show Mr Trump and Mr Biden standing precariously on flooring that is being cut from below. The reader is left to guess which one might suddenly take a tumble.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Nothing conjures up notions of “shock” and “act of God” better than lightning. So our design team also concocted a bolt from on high striking the presidential podium, symbolising an unfortunate event that might lay one of the candidates low. Or perhaps, since we were talking about things with huge consequences, we could show the White House sinking into a black hole? Maybe this was a bit over the top.

;

;Since luck is involved—and one of the candidates used to run casinos—we toyed with a gambling theme. We tried showing a cascade of cards, face down so we couldn't see how good or bad they were. Look harder, and it was possible to see Mr Trump's profile in Republican red and Mr Biden's in Democratic blue. The same idea could be conveyed with three cups and a ball, as in a shell game. However, shell games are usually rigged, and we didn't want to suggest that about the election. Too many people distrust the voting machines already.

;

;What about a rabbit, ready to be plucked from a conjurer's hat? First we fashioned its ears out of political bumper stickers. Then we tried a drawing of a bunny emerging from a ballot box. This was adorable, but not quite right. The surprises we were talking about did not involve magic or trickery.

;

;The race is so close that something small could change the result. So how about a butterfly bending a flagpole bearing the Stars and Stripes? Some erudite colleagues quibbled that this is not how the “butterfly effect” works, but we developed it into a cover anyway.

;

;In the end, the image we liked best showed the two candidates setting off along a campaign trail strewn with banana skins. One of them could slip, upending the race. The first design, with regular bananas, was too quiet, so our designers made it more like pop art, evoking an album cover Andy Warhol did for the Velvet Underground. The only remaining problem was that the banana was too big. We asked the design team to do some “banana optimisation”—not an instruction they'd heard before—and the result was a very appealing cover.

His wife, Yulia Navalnaya, has vowed to continue his work. America prepared new sanctions against Russia.

;

;The ;Russian regime; has a long reach hitting its enemies. A Russian helicopter pilot who defected to Ukraine was found dead in Spain. The head of Russia's foreign intelligence service described the man as a “traitor and criminal”.

;Russia executed several Ukrainian prisoners of war after capturing ;;Avdiivka;;, according to reports. Ukraine's new commander-in-chief, Colonel General Oleksandr Syrsky, withdrew his troops from the eastern town to stop them being encircled. ;;Polish farmers; blockaded Poland's border with Ukraine, stepping up their protest against Ukrainian grain imports, which they blame for undermining their market. The protests present a quandary for the new Polish government, which says it backs the farmers, but is also highly supportive of Ukraine.

;

;;Finland; made its strongest accusation yet that Russia is gathering groups of illegal migrants and sending them over the border. The interior minister said that thousands of migrants were waiting to cross, after 1,300 had entered between August and December (before that just one person a day was crossing over). New laws are being prepared to boost border security.

;;

;Sunak is sunk

;

;;Britain's; Conservative Party ;lost two by -elections; to the opposition Labour Party, the latest in a run of defeats for the Tories. By-election losses for governing parties are not uncommon, but the swing to Labour far exceeded the party's national poll lead of 20% over the Conservatives. In Wellingborough, hitherto one of the Tories' safest seats, the fall in the party's share of the vote was the biggest since the second world war.

;

;Sir Lindsay Hoyle came under pressure to step down as ;speaker; of Britain's House of Commons following his botched handling of a vote on a ceasefire in Gaza. Sir Lindsay is accused by the Conservatives and Scottish National Party of favouring a Labour amendment that would have allowed Labour ;MP;s to vote for a “humanitarian ceasefire”. Sir Lindsay said he did this because he was worried about ;MP;s' “security”. Some ;MP;s say they have faced threats from radical supporters of Palestine for not backing a stop to the war.

;

;

;Benny Gantz, a member of the ;Israeli; war cabinet, said that unless the remaining hostages who were seized by Hamas on October 7th are freed by March 10th, Israel would launch a ground offensive in Rafah, the city in southern ;Gaza; to which many Palestinians have fled. March 10th is also the probable start of Ramadan. Efforts to broker a ceasefire continued in Cairo, although Qatari mediators said progress was slow. The death toll in Gaza passed 29,000. Meanwhile, America vetoed a ;UN; ;resolution; demanding an immediate ceasefire in Gaza. The United States is proposing its own resolution calling for a temporary ceasefire which also warns Israel not to invade Rafah.

;The World Food Programme, a ;UN; agency, announced that it was pausing food deliveries to northern Gaza, because ;aid convoys; faced chaos and violence there “due to the collapse of civil order”.

;

;;Syria; blamed Israel for an air strike on a building in Damascus that killed at least two people. Israel has carried out a dozen attacks in Syria this year on targets connected to Iran.

;

;;;Senegal;'s; Constitutional Council slapped down an attempt by the government to postpone the presidential election, which had been scheduled for February 25th. The council said it must now take place as soon as possible.

;

;Israel and ;Brazil; became; ;ensnarled in a; ;diplomatic tangle, which started when Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva compared Israel's military action in Gaza to “when Hitler decided to kill the Jews”. Israel's foreign minister said Brazil's left-wing president would be “persona non grata” in the country until he retracted the statement. In response, Brazil withdrew its ambassador from Israel.

;

;A judge in ;;Haiti;; investigating the assassination in 2021 of the then-president, Jovenel Moïse, charged his wife with involvement in the killing. The indictment says that Martine Moïse, who was injured in the attack, had given contradictory evidence and was herself interested in power. Some, including Ms Moïse, say the charges are political. Her lawyer has denied that she played any role in the murder.

;

;The Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz and Pakistan People's Party cemented a coalition agreement, following an election in which Tehreek-e-Insaf, the party of Imran Khan, ;Pakistan's; imprisoned opposition leader, came first. The ;PML-N; and ;PPP; will form a government with the support of smaller parties. Shehbaz Sharif of the ;PML-N; will again become prime minister, a job he held until last August. The ;PPP';s Asif Ali Zardari, widower of Benazir Bhutto, a slain former prime minister, will return as president.

;

;At least 26 people were killed in tribal clashes in ;Papua New Guinea;. Local police said it was the worst outbreak of violence they had seen in the remote Highlands area, where tribal conflicts have worsened because of an influx of illegal weapons. A state of emergency was declared in Port Moresby, the country's capital, last month, after riots killed 16 people. The government is struggling to impose order.

;

;Chinese coast guards boarded a Taiwanese tourist boat that was visiting the Kinmen islands, which lie just 10km (six miles) off the coast of ;China; but belong to ;Taiwan;. A few days earlier two Chinese fishermen drowned after they were chased away from the Kinmens by Taiwanese coast guards. Responding to Taiwan's protests, China said there was no such thing as “restricted” waters.

A judge's recent order for Mr Trump to pay $355m, plus interest, for cooking the books at the Trump Organisation won't help. He has taken to selling gold-coloured Trump-branded sneakers for $399 a pair to raise money.
